description.narrative: Output Based Aid "kuponger" för mödravård som subventionerar kostnaden för gravida kvinnor och nyblivna mödrar till kvalitativ hälsovård. Programmet genonförs i samarbete med Världsbanken

Output Based Aid voucher programme for maternal care to subsidy the cost of access to quality ante-natal, maternal and post-natal care for pregnant and newly delivered mothers and their babies. The project is implemented in cooperation with the World Bank GPOBA.
The objective of the project is to increase access to skilled care among poor women living in rural and disadvantaged areas during pregnancy, delivery and post natal follow up.

participating-org.narrative: IBRD/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Introduction The Uganda Reproductive Health Voucher Project (URHVP) is supported by Sida through the World Bank (WB), with Marie Stopes Uganda (MSU) as the main implementing partner, though the programme is being "owned" and managed by the Ministry of Health (MoH). The URHVP falls under Sida’s support to the WB Global Program on Output Based Aid (GPOBA), recently rebranded to Global Program on Results Based Aid (GPRBA), where the overall agreement is managed by Sida HQ. The project finally started in 2015 after serious delays and it is now in its fourth year. To date 214 facilities (102 from South Western and 112 from Eastern Uganda) are enrolled in the project, providing quality maternal health services to poor, rural women in 25 districts (13 in Eastern and 12 in South West Uganda). Health facilities/service providers are both public, private not for profit (PNFP) and private for profit (PFP). The aim of the URHVP is to increase facility-based deliveries and safe motherhood. Poor women are offered a voucher for 4,000 UGX (about $1 US), which covers four ante-natal care (ANC) visits, a delivery and one post-natal care (PNC) visit. Since last year, the voucher also includes post-partum family planning (PPFP) services. The women can choose whether to deliver at a public, PNFP or PFP clinic. The facilities enrolled in the project are reimbursed for the services provided and clinic staff also receives support in terms of capacity building through training and providing medical equipment. Results At the end of the second quarter of the fourth year of project implementation, a cumulative total of 143,889 (92% of project target) deliveries had been supported, 17 percent being women/girls below 19 years of age. The proportion of pregnant women that attended at least one ANC was maintained above 90%, while those returning for postnatal care services stands at 43%. Overall, the uptake of PPFP services has increased from 24% to 43%. Time taken before reimbursing a submitted claim is still at 48 days, due to a lengthy processes between requisition by VMA and release of funds from the MoH. Based on observations from a field visit carried out in May 2018, the project has contributed to tangible results, reflected in an increased number of health facility deliveries, ANC and PNC visits in enrolled facilities. District ownership of and involvement/ interest in the project is strong and client feedback shows that the population are very positive towards the vouchers. The implementing partner, MSU, is doing an excellent job and their monitoring and follow up of the project was rather impressive. The project has increased the capacity of health facilities as well as improved quality of services, however sustainability is still a key concern and it is today not clear what will happen after the project ends in December 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
